title: Agrostis
text:
Agrostis (bent or bentgrass) is a large and very nearly <a href="Cosmopolitan%20distribution">cosmopolitan</a> genus of plants in the <a href="Poaceae">grass family</a>, found in nearly all the countries in the world. It has been bred as a <a href="Genetically%20modified%20organism">GMO</a> creeping bent grass.
Species.
Hundreds of species formerly listed in the genus "Agrostis" have been moved to other genera, including "<a href="Achnatherum">Achnatherum</a>", "<a href="Aira">Aira</a>", "<a href="Alloteropsis">Alloteropsis</a>", "<a href="Apera">Apera</a>", "<a href="Arundinella">Arundinella</a>", "<a href="Calamagrostis">Calamagrostis</a>", "<a href="Chaetopogon">Chaetopogon</a>", "<a href="Chionochloa">Chionochloa</a>", "<a href="Chloris%20%28plant%29">Chloris</a>", "<a href="Cinna%20%28plant%29">Cinna</a>", "<a href="Colpodium">Colpodium</a>", "<a href="Crypsis">Crypsis</a>", "<a href="Cynodon">Cynodon</a>", "<a href="Deschampsia">Deschampsia</a>", "<a href="Dichelachne">Dichelachne</a>", "<a href="Digitaria">Digitaria</a>", "<a href="Eremochloa">Eremochloa</a>", "<a href="Eriochloa">Eriochloa</a>", "<a href="Eustachys">Eustachys</a>", "<a href="Gastridium">Gastridium</a>", "<a href="Graphephorum">Graphephorum</a>", "<a href="Gymnopogon">Gymnopogon</a>", "<a href="Lachnagrostis">Lachnagrostis</a>", "<a href="Leptochloa">Leptochloa</a>", "<a href="Muhlenbergia">Muhlenbergia</a>", "<a href="Pentameris">Pentameris</a>", "<a href="Phippsia">Phippsia</a>", "<a href="Piptatherum">Piptatherum</a>", "<a href="Poa">Poa</a>", "<a href="Polypogon">Polypogon</a>", "<a href="Puccinellia">Puccinellia</a>", "<a href="Reimarochloa">Reimarochloa</a>", "<a href="Relchela">Relchela</a>", "<a href="Schismus">Schismus</a>", "<a href="Sporobolus">Sporobolus</a>" and " <a href="Zingeria">Zingeria</a>".
Uses.
Some species of bents are commonly used for <a href="lawn">lawn</a> grass. This is a desirable grass for <a href="Golf%20course%23Teeing%20area">golf course teeing areas</a>, <a href="Golf%20course%23Fairway%20and%20rough">fairways</a>, and <a href="Golf%20course%23Greens">greens</a>.
Bentgrass is used in turf applications for its numerous advantages: it can be mowed to a very short length without damage, it can handle a great amount of foot traffic, it has a shallow root system that is thick and dense allowing it to be seeded and grow rather easily, and it has a pleasing, deep green appearance. The name "bent" refers to the shallow roots, which bend just below the surface of the soil to propagate laterally.
Creeping bent.
"<a href="Agrostis%20stolonifera">Agrostis stolonifera</a>" is the most commonly used species of "Agrostis". Historically, it was often called <a href="Orcheston">Orcheston</a> long grass, after a village on <a href="Salisbury%20Plain">Salisbury Plain</a>, England. It is cultivated almost exclusively on golf courses, especially on putting greens. Creeping bent aggressively produces horizontal stems, called <a href="stolons">stolons</a>, that run along the soil's surface. These allow creeping bent to form dense stands under conducive conditions and outcompete bunch-type grass and broadleaf weeds. As such, if infested in a home lawn, it can become a troublesome weed problem. The leaves of the bentgrass are long and slender. It can quickly take over a home lawn if it is not controlled and has very shallow roots.
The <a href="Scotts%20Miracle-Gro%20Company">Scotts Miracle-Gro Company</a> and <a href="Monsanto">Monsanto</a> genetically engineered creeping bent to be <a href="glyphosate">glyphosate</a>-tolerant under Monsanto's <a href="Roundup%20Ready">Roundup Ready</a> trademark, as "one of the first wind-pollinated, perennial, and highly outcrossing transgenic crops". In 2003, Scotts planted it as part of a large (about 160 ha) field trial in central Oregon near <a href="Madras%2C%20Oregon">Madras</a>. In 2004, its pollen was found to have reached wild growing bentgrass populations up to 14 kilometres away. Cross-pollinating "<a href="Agrostis%20gigantea">Agrostis gigantea</a>" was even found at a distance of 21 kilometres. Scotts could not remove all genetically engineered plants and in 2007, the <a href="Animal%20and%20Plant%20Health%20Inspection%20Service">Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service</a> fined them $500,000 for non-compliance with <a href="Plant%20Protection%20Act">Plant Protection Act</a> regulations.
Common bent.
"<a href="Agrostis%20capillaris">Agrostis capillaris</a>", or colonial bent, was brought to America from Europe. This was the type of grass that was used on the lawns of most estates. It is the tallest of the bents with very fine texture and like most bent grasses grows very densely. Although this species has been used on golf courses and sporting fields it is better suited for lawns. Colonial bent is fairly easy to grow from seeds and fertilization of the lawn is not as intense. This grass also takes longer to establish than creeping bent. However it does not require the intense maintenance.
Velvet bent.
"<a href="Agrostis%20canina">Agrostis canina</a>" gets its name for the velvet appearance that this grass produces. It has the finest texture of all the bent grasses. This grass was used in Europe for estate lawns and golf courses because it could be cut so short. Velvet bent grass requires similar upkeep and maintenance to creeping bent. Velvet bent has recently had a resurgence in the UK due to the high demands on greens from inclement weather and speed expectations. This species also has a lighter color than the two previous species.
